newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugoslav '95 GDP far below govt estimate-Institute.
newsitem.headline: Yugoslav '95 GDP far below govt estimate-Institute.

text.p: Yugoslavia's gross domestic product in 1995 was less than $10 billion, well below the government's figure of $15.9 billion, an economic think-tank said on Monday.

"Our 1995 GDP was between $9 billion and $10 billion," Stojan Stamenkovic of the Institute of Economic Sciences (IEN) told a news conference and urged the government to review the way it calculated GDP.
Yugoslavia has not settled the issue of its external debt following the breakup of the former Yugoslavia, and a wrongly calculated GDP could affect its debt service terms and benefits.

"Benefits are directly linked to a level of the country's development, and the key figure is its per capita income. The government claims it stands at $1,510 but we think it hardly reaches $1,000," Stamenkovic said.

Stamenkovic said the official calculation was based on an unrealistic average dinar-dollar rate. Instead of taking a dinar rate of 2.87 to the dollar, the government should have used a more realistic 3.68 dinars to the dollar.
"This correction alone would reduce the estimated GDP from $15.9 billion to $12.4 billion," Stamenkovic said.
When replacement costs of real estate, including housing, and the wrong calculation of inventories are taken into account, GDP falls to between $9 and $10 billion, he added.

The government may have been trying to hide its high public spending, he said. "If their figures are accepted, public spending accounts for around 40 percent of GDP. But if our calculation is used, public spending jumps to 70 percent of GDP," Stamenkovic told Reuters.
He said IEN refrained from forecasting 1996 GDP because the effects of huge internal indebtedness and deep economic recession are yet to be calculated.
Yugoslavia's gross foreign debt amounted to some $9 billion, excluding so-called non-allocated debt.
"Our whole GDP is indebted. This means we should have no budget and pay no salaries, but only service debts. But it does not happen like that in practice," Stamenkovic said.

Yugoslavia will have to reorganise its debt and negotiate new terms for debt payment. Meanwhile it will have to start paying interest, he added. "We talk about some $600 million to pay back interest, and for that we need foreign help," Stamenkovic said.
